# Getting Started

## Install and launching R packages

This hands-on uses a few ggplot2 related packages.

-   **tidyverse**: for data import and ggplot2
-   **ggrepel**: for labels (avoid overlapping)
-   **ggthemes**: extra themes
-   **patchwork**: combine plots

```{r}
pacman::p_load(tidyverse, ggrepel, ggthemes, patchwork)
```

## Importing the data

```{r}
exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")
```

# Beyond ggplot2 Annotation: ggrepel

If I label many points, the labels will overlap and looks messy.

## Without ggrepel

```{r}
ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.5) +
  geom_label(aes(label = ID),
             hjust = .5,
             vjust = -.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 100),
                  ylim = c(0, 100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")
```

## Working with ggrepel

Now I use `geom_label_repel()` to reduce overlapping.

```{r}
ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.5) +
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID),
                   fontface = "bold",
                   max.overlaps = 50) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 100),
                  ylim = c(0, 100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")
```

# Beyond ggplot2 Themes: ggthemes

Themes control background, grid line, text style, etc.\
Here I use the same chart and just change theme.

## Default theme (theme_gray)

```{r}
p_hist <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
                 aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "black",
                 fill = "grey") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

p_hist + theme_gray()
```

## ggthemes example: theme_economist

```{r}
p_hist + theme_economist()
```

## Another ggthemes example: theme_fivethirtyeight

```{r}
p_hist + theme_fivethirtyeight()
```

# Beyond Single Graph: patchwork

Sometimes we need to put multiple plots in one figure.

## Create a few plots

```{r}
p1 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "black",
                 fill = "grey") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 100)) +
  ggtitle("Maths")

p2 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
             aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "black",
                 fill = "grey") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 100)) +
  ggtitle("English")

p3 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
             aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 100),
                  ylim = c(0, 100)) +
  ggtitle("English vs Maths")
```

## Combining two ggplot2 graphs

```{r}
p1 + p2
```

## Combining three ggplot2 graphs

```{r}
(p1 / p2) | p3
```

## Adding tags

```{r}
((p1 / p2) | p3) +
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'I')
```

## Inserting a plot

```{r}
p3 + inset_element(p2,
                   left = 0.02,
                   bottom = 0.7,
                   right = 0.5,
                   top = 1)
```

## Apply a theme to the whole patchwork

```{r}
((p1 / p2) | p3) & theme_economist()
```
